p: Identifying the asymptomatic or presymptomatic carriers will be impossible without testing. Many questions have ensured regarding testing, including the availability of validated rapid tests, who should be tested, and the process of obtaining specimens. The CDC has recommended that clinicians work with their local and state health departments to coordinate testing through public health laboratories. Also physicians should use clinical judgment to determine whether a patient who presents for care has symptoms of an influenza-like illness or symptoms compatible with COVID-19 to make a decision regarding testing (guidelines available at: https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/downloads/priority-testing-patients.pdf). For patients scheduled for in-patient surgery the guidance for testing by each institution and/or state should be followed. As of March 24, the CDC guidance for testing priority showed that oral and maxillofacial surgeons (healthcare workers and first responders) should be considered priorityÂ 3.
